awd_titl_txt: Dissertation Research:  Mechanisms and consequences of flexibility in mutualistic relationships
awd_abstract_narration:
At the foundation of many biological communities are mutualisms in which a relatively large, long-lived host organism provides habitat to symbiotic partners in return for reproductive, energetic and/or defensive resources. With many partnerships available, flexibility in partner selection can provide the host organism the versatility to associate with the optimal partner for a particular environment. However, it also introduces the potential for cheating and competition among different symbiont types, which may draw essential resources away from the host and cause a breakdown of the host-symbiont mutualism. Corals and their genetically diverse but functionally similar algal symbionts provide an exceptional model system to better understand the ecological balance of these processes. This research will measure resource acquisition and exchange for a variety of laboratory induced coral-algal combinations to determine whether hosting multiple symbiont types has a positive, negative or null affect on the amount of resources provided to the coral host. 
The proposed research encompasses methods from multiple disciplines, molecular biology, carbon chemistry, photochemistry and statistical modeling to advance our understanding of a fundamental ecological interaction. These ecological models will be broadly applicable to host-symbiont mutualisms that are essential to terrestrial, freshwater and marine communities, aiding in the management and conservation of these areas. In addition, through mentorship and collaboration with two undergraduate students, the importance of mutualism ecology will be communicated through scientific, classroom and public platforms. This includes attendance at scientific conferences, developing teaching materials for K-12 classrooms and outreach efforts through the Aquarium of Niagara.

por.por_cntn:
Reef-building corals rely on a partnership with a dinoflagellate algae (genus Symbiodinium) that lives inside coral tissues. The majority of the energetic and nutrient requirements of the coral are produced by this alga via photosynthesis and shared with the coral host. This is a true mutualistic symbiosis similar to many foundational species including trees that gain nutritional benefits from bacteria and fungus on their roots. There are many species of Symbiodinium, which are all unique in physiology and their compatibility with particular coral hosts. In some corals, the dominant Symbiodinium species changes with changes in the environment, such as increase sea temperatures, yet we know little about how these shifts in symbiont species occur: What controls the genetic diversity of these algal symbionts? How does diversity affects nutrient uptake and sharing within the coral-Symbiodinium symbiosis? These questions were the focus of this study.

This experiment traced the uptake of carbon and nitrogen from seawater to algae to coral host in order to better understand the nutrient exchange relationship. Carbon is used for making carbohydrates for energy, while carbon and nitrogen together are necessary for building proteins necessary for growth. Specifically, our experiment looked at whether two different species of Symbiodinium within the same coral host would compete for nutrients and whether this competition would result in nutritional consequences for the coral host. We found differences between the two algal types in terms of their ability to take up nutrients as well as how much of those nutrients were shared with the coral host. Where both species were present carbon uptake could be predicted by multiplying the proportion of each symbiont type present by the amount of carbon it acquired when alone. This suggests that while the two algae differed in their physiology and compatibility with the host, the two algae did not interfere with each other. The relationship between the abundance of each Symbiodinium species and nitrogen uptake was more complex. For one of the Symbiodinium species (S. microadriaticum), higher symbiont densities (number of algae per area of coral tissue) within the tissues translated to decreased nitrogen uptake. Limited nitrogen uptake with increasing densities could be a sign of coral host control of its symbiont population (which occurs in many other biological systems), or competition among symbiont types. When the coral hosted 60% or more of S. minutum, the other algal species tested it received a constant amount of nitrogen regardless of the density of symbiont cells within the host tissue. Thus, when S. minutum, the symbiont which provided more carbon is dominant the coral-symbiont relationship appears more stable and more beneficial for the host. This information can help researchers to understand the cost of shifts in symbiont communities, the nutrient consequences of symbiont shifts that increase the thermal tolerance of reef building corals, and also to understand the ecology and evolution of similar host-symbiont systems.
